revision.text: #REDIRECT [[IPTV]] {{R to initialism}}

{{Infobox website |name = Kelkoo Group |logo = Kg logo.png |collapsible = |collapsetext = |screenshot= |caption= |company_type = |traded_as = |foundation = 1999 |founder = Pierre Chappaz, Mauricio Lopez |location = |area_served = |key_people = Richard Stables, CEO 2009- |industry = [[Internet]] |products = |services = [[Price comparison service]], [[Online advertising]] |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |assets = |equity = |owner = Jamplant Ltd |num_employees = |subsid = MonsieurPrix.com, ShopGenie.co.uk |url = [http://www.kelkoo.com kelkoo.com] |programming_language = |website_type = [[E-commerce]] |language = |advertising = |launch_date = {{start date and age|1999|11|30}} |alexa = }}
'''Kelkoo''' is a European [[price comparison service]] founded in [[France]] in 1999.<ref name="privateequityonline1">{{Cite web |url=http://www.privateequityonline.com/Article.aspx?article=32455&hashID=AFB0D0B34E33B4044A7ADEF3381482A02E58D183 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-12-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715114944/http://www.privateequityonline.com/Article.aspx?article=32455&hashID=AFB0D0B34E33B4044A7ADEF3381482A02E58D183 |archive-date=2011-07-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2000 Kelkoo merged with Zoomit, Dondecomprar and Shopgenie. The company was bought by [[Yahoo!]] on March 26, 2004.<ref name="autogenerated1">http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3570775.stm</ref> and was subsequently sold by Yahoo to Jamplant, a [[United Kingdom|British]] private equity firm, in 2008. On October 13, 2016 Kelkoo, the ecommerce advertising and price comparison platform, announced the acquisition of LeGuide group, <ref name="kelkoo.com">https://www.kelkoo.com/kelkoo-acquires-leguide-group/</ref> updating its branding to reflect the acquisition: Kelkoo Group.
Kelkoo Group operates in 22 countries ([[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Brazil]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Netherlands]], [[Norway]], [[Poland]], [[Portugal]], [[Russia]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]], [[UK]], [[United States]] and [[Mexico]]).
Kelkoo Group is headquartered in [[London]], UK; with operating offices in [[Paris]], [[Grenoble]], [[Vilnius]], [[Oslo]] and [[Milan]]. Richard Stables became chief executive officer ([[CEO]]) of Kelkoo Group in 2009. == Company History== Kelkoo was founded in 1999 by [[Pierre Chappaz]] and [[Mauricio Lopez]].<ref name="autogenerated2">http://news.cnet.com/Yahoo-says-bienvenue-to-Kelkoo/2100-1038_3-5179775.html</ref> Initial funding of $3 million was provided by [[Banexi Ventures]] and [[Innovacom]]. Once Kelkoo merged with 3 other European businesses, it absorbed those founders into one single collective, consisting of [[Per Siljubergsåsen]], [[William Klippgen]], [[Philip Wilkinson (entrepreneur)|Philip Wilkinson]], and Jorge Garcia<ref>http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jorge-juan-garcia-alonso/10/372/328</ref>
In April 2000, within days of each other, Kelkoo merged with Spanish-based Dondecomprar.com<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc.aspx?DOCID=1G1:61906531&print=yes&ctrlInfo=Round20%3AMode20a%3ADocG%3AResult&ao= Spain's Dondecomprar.com merged with Kelkoo.com]</ref> and UK based competitor [[ShopGenie]], founded by [[Philip Wilkinson (entrepreneur)|Philip Wilkinson]].<ref>[http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/350621 European Merger Creates E-Commerce Giant]</ref> In September of the same year, Kelkoo merged with Norway-based [[Zoomit.com]],<ref>[http://www.kelkoo.co.uk/b/a/co_5261_128501-consumer-releases-zoomit-merger.html Consumer Releases: Zoomit Merger<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> paying the Zoomit-shareholders in shares amounting to a third of Kelkoo's total equity making [[Zoomit.com]] the largest entity within "new" Kelkoo.
In June 2003, the company partnered with the European arm of the [[Microsoft]] site [[MSN]] to provide shopping listings.<ref>[http://www.e-consultancy.com/news-blog/150160/kelkoo-seals-msn-deal.html Kelkoo seals MSN deal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927221026/http://www.e-consultancy.com/news-blog/150160/kelkoo-seals-msn-deal.html |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> A similar deal was announced in June 2004 with [[Ask.com]] (formerly Ask Jeeves).
On March 26, 2004, Kelkoo was bought by [[Yahoo! Inc]] for €450 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |title=Yahoo! Inc. - Company Timeline |work=[[Wayback Machine]] |date=2008-07-13 |accessdate=2016-07-19 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080713214826/http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |archivedate=2008-07-13 |df= }}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1"/> Yahoo explained this move as providing advertisers with the ability to target individual products.<ref>[http://docs.yahoo.com/docs/pr/release1160.html Yahoo! to Acquire Kelkoo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701084008/http://docs.yahoo.com/docs/pr/release1160.html |date=2007-07-01 }}</ref>
In November 2008, Kelkoo was sold by [[Yahoo! Inc]] to the private equity firm Jamplant Ltd.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
In October 2016, Kelkoo acquired LeGuide group, the price comparison market leader in France. This newly formed group of two historical players had a major impact on the industry, with Kelkoo becoming the European leader in shopping comparison, a unique international position.<ref name="kelkoo.com"/> Kelkoo Group has 20 years of experience in ecommerce, digital advertising and consumer analytics, and is committed to driving exceptional revenue growth for merchants and publishers.
===Company name=== The name "Kelkoo" is a [[phonetic]] spelling meaning primarily the French phrase "Quel coût?", meaning "At what price?". It can also be understood as "Quel coup", meaning "What a bargain".<ref>[http://www.kelkoo.co.uk/co_5203-how-to-use-kelkoo-frequently-asked-questions.html#8 Kelkoo FAQ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329135628/http://www.kelkoo.co.uk/co_5203-how-to-use-kelkoo-frequently-asked-questions.html |date=2010-03-29 }}</ref>
==Business model== Kelkoo has been profitable since Q4 2002. Similar to other [[price comparison service]]s in how it operates, Kelkoo has focused much of its marketing on capturing users through [[Search engine optimization|SEO]] and launching partner sites<ref>http://www.crunchbase.com/company/kelkoo</ref> including [[ITV Network|ITV]]'s [[PriceTerrier.com]].<ref>[http://paidcontent.co.uk/article/419-itvs-priceterrier-goes-live-this-dog-stands-alone/ ITV’s PriceTerrier Goes Live]</ref>
In addition to being a price comparison site, '''Kelkoo''' also offers an API webservice where other price comparison websites, such as [[PriceSpin.com]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pricespin.net/partners.html |title=PriceSpin Data Partners |access-date=2011-01-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724021606/http://www.pricespin.net/partners.html |archive-date=2011-07-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[:Category:Shopping price comparison websites|shopping comparison website]], and [[SmartShopper.com]]<ref>[http://smartshopper.com/Partners/OurPartners.aspx SmartShopper Partners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811072836/http://www.smartshopper.com/Partners/OurPartners.aspx |date=2010-08-11 }}</ref> price comparison [[Plug-in (computing)|browser add-on]], use data and content from Kelkoo's database.<ref>[http://developer.kelkoo.com/shopping-services/ Kelkoo Shopping Web Services]</ref> This is a [[Revenue sharing|shared revenue]] business model. Kelkoo offers an [[Affiliate marketing|affiliate commission]] to the partner sites who use their data for every [[Pay per click|qualified click]] that they generate.
Kelkoo launched their [http://www.kelkoo.com.br Brazil website] in 2012, deciding on Brazil as a market over India and China.<ref>[http://thinking.grant-thornton.co.uk/emergingmarkets/index.php/article/kelkoos_bric_comparison_picks_out_brazil_for_growth/ Kelkoo arrives in Brazil] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405070342/http://thinking.grant-thornton.co.uk/emergingmarkets/index.php/article/kelkoos_bric_comparison_picks_out_brazil_for_growth |date=2013-04-05 }}</ref>
===In popular culture=== In October 2005 a book on Kelkoo appeared in French called ''Ils ont réussi leur start-up! La success-story de Kelkoo''.<ref>[https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/2744061956 Amazon.fr : Ils ont réussi leur Start-up ! : La Success Story de Kelkoo: Livres: Julien Codorniou, Cyrille de Lasteyrie, Pierre Chappaz<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> written by Julien Codorniou and Cyrille de Lasteyrie.
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: List of commercial open-source applications and services

revision.comment: rmv - nn, unlikely redlink, changed name to current full title
revision.text:
The purpose of this table is to provide reference information about the provenance and history of notable [[commercial open-source applications]], adopting [[Business models for open-source software]], alphabetized by the product/service name. It is not to be used or interpreted as an advertisement for the vendors. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Product or service name'''
(business models used) ! Commercial vendor ! Description ! Current version ! Open source
Project name ! Ver 1.0 Date |- | [[389 Directory Server]] (3,4) | Red Hat | LDAP-compliant directory server | ? | Fedora Directory Server | ? |- | [[Abiquo]] (1,3,4) | Abiquo | Cloud management | 2.6 | Abiquo | 2008 |- | [[AdaControl]] (4) | Adalog | Source-code controller and coding standard checker for [[Ada (programming language)|Ada]] | 1.13r8 | AdaControl | 2004 |- | [[Alfresco (software)|Alfresco]] (1,3,4) | Alfresco | Enterprise content management, web content management | 2.2 | Alfresco | 2006 |- | [[Asterisk (PBX)|Asterisk]] (1,4) | [[Digium]] | PBX server / telephony toolkit | 1.6.2.1 | [[Asterisk PBX|Asterisk]] | 2004{{cite web|title = Asterisk Version 1.0 released at Astricon|publisher = VentureVoIP|date = 24 September 2004|url =http://www.venturevoip.com/news.php?rssid=108|accessdate = 26 January 2010}} |- | [[Bacula]] (1,3,4) | Bacula | Data backup/recovery | 2.7 | Bacula | ? |- | [[Berkeley DB]] (?) | [[Oracle Corporation]] | DBMS engines | 4.6, 3.2, 2.3 | Berkeley DB, Java edition, XML edition

page.title: List of drugs used by militaries

revision.text:
[[Military|Militaries]] worldwide have used or are using various [[psychoactive drugs]] to [[Performance-enhancing substance|improve performance]] of soldiers by suppressing hunger, increasing the ability to sustain effort without food, increasing and lengthening [[wakefulness]] and concentration, suppressing [[fear]], reducing empathy, and improving reflexes and memory-recall, amongst other things.{{cite web |last1=Stoker |first1=Liam |title=Creating Supermen: battlefield performance enhancing drugs |url=https://www.army-technology.com/features/featurecreating-supermen-battlefield-performance-enhancing-drugs/ |website=Army Technology |publisher=[[Verdict Media Limited]] |accessdate=22 June 2018 |date=14 April 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Kamienski|first1=Lukasz|title=The Drugs That Built a Super Soldier|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/04/the-drugs-that-built-a-super-soldier/477183/|publisher=The Atlantic|date=8 April 2016|accessdate=22 June 2018}} ==Contemporary== {{expand list|date=January 2017}} For drugs that recently were or currently are being used by militaries.
Administration tends to include strict [[Clinical supervision|medical supervision]] and prior briefing of the medical risks.{{cn|date=January 2017}}
[[Caffeine]], [[diet pill]]s, [[painkiller]]s and [[alcohol]] are not featured in the list, neither is non-administrated, illegal usage. {|class="wikitable" |- ! Substance !! class="unsortable" | Description !! USA !! PRC !! India !! Germany !! UK !! France !! Turkey |- |[[Amphetamine]]
(and close derivatives)|| [[US Air Force]] and potentially other branches prescribed it to pilots for long endurance flights or for critical missions. ||{{Yes-No|Until 2017}}{{cite web|title=‘Go pills’: A war on drugs?|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/3071789/ns/us_news-only/t/go-pills-war-drugs/|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=27 February 2004}}{{cite web|last1=Saletan|first1=William|title=The War on Sleep|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/superman/2013/05/sleep_deprivation_in_the_military_modafinil_and_the_arms_race_for_soldiers.html|publisher=Slate|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=29 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Combat Pilots on Speed|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=123779&page=1|publisher=ABC News |date=6 January 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131230719/http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=123779&page=1 |archivedate=2011-01-31}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{Yes-No|Until 1970s/1988([[East Germany|East]])}}{{cite web|title=Die Super-Soldaten, die auf den Schlachtfeldern der Zukunft kämpfen werden|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/de/read/die-maechtigsten-super-soldaten-der-militaergeschichte-captain-america-avengers--Von-Exoskeletten-und-Soldate-auf-smart-drugs|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=5 January 2017|language=de}}{{cite web|title="Pervitin" - Großvater des Crystal Meth|url=http://www.spiegel.de/einestages/von-pervitin-bis-breaking-bad-die-karriere-der-droge-crystal-meth-a-951122.html|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=5 January 2017}}{{cite web|title="Wunderpille" Pervitin - Drogeneinnahme für das Vaterland|url=https://www.3sat.de/page/?source=/scobel/162187/index.html|publisher=3Sat|accessdate=5 January 2017}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}} |- |[[Cocaine]] || || {{unknown}} ||{{unknown}}||{{Yes-No|Until 2012}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||Often suffered sleep deprivation so this was used to help |- |[[Fenethylline]] || Used by [[ISIS]]{{cite news|last1=Todd|first1=Brian|last2=McConnell|first2=Dugald|title=Syria fighters may be fueled by amphetamines|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/20/world/syria-fighters-amphetamine/index.html|accessdate=22 November 2015|work=[[CNN]]|date=21 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Captagon, ISIS's favorite amphetamine, explained|url=https://www.vox.com/world/2015/11/20/9769264/captagon-isis-drug|publisher=Vox|accessdate=5 January 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2014/jan/13/captagon-amphetamine-syria-war-middle-east |title=Captagon: the amphetamine fuelling Syria's civil war |first=Jon |last=Henley |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=13 January 2014 |accessdate=31 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=This is the tiny pill fuelling the Syrian civil war|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/captagon-the-tiny-amphetamine-pill-fueling-the-syrian-civil-war-and-turning-fighters-into-superhuman-a6740601.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=19 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=These Are the People Making Captagon, the Drug ISIS Fighters Take to Feel ‘Invincible’|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/12/men-making-captagon-the-drug-fueling-isis.html|publisher=Daily Intelligencer|accessdate=5 January 2017}} || {{unknown}} ||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}} |- |[[Modafinil]] || Militaries of several countries are known to have expressed interest in modafinil as an alternative to [[amphetamine]]—the drug traditionally employed in combat situations where troops face [[sleep deprivation]], such as during lengthy missions. The [[France|French]] government indicated that the [[French Foreign Legion|Foreign Legion]] used modafinil during certain covert operations.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} The [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] commissioned research into modafinil{{cite news |author=Wheeler B |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6083840.stm |title=BBC report on MoD research into modafinil |publisher=BBC News |date=October 26, 2006 |accessdate=July 4, 2012}} from [[Qinetiq|QinetiQ]] and spent £300,000 on one investigation.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/health/mod-s-secret-pep-pill-to-keep-forces-awake-1-1387967 |title=MoD's secret pep pill to keep forces awake |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=February 27, 2005 |accessdate=December 31, 2013}} In 2011, the [[Indian Air Force]] announced that modafinil was included in contingency plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.punemirror.in/article/2/201102162011021606331644587714a65/Pilot-pill-project.html |title=Pilot pill project |work=News – City |publisher=PuneMirror |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=July 4, 2012}}

In the [[United States]] military, modafinil has been approved for use on certain [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] missions, and it is being investigated for other uses.{{cite web |url=http://www.hep.afrl.af.mil/HEPF/Policy/modafinil.pdf |title=Modafinil and management of aircrew fatigue |author1=Taylor GP, Jr |author2=Keys RE |date=December 1, 2003 |format=PDF |work= |publisher=United States Department of the Air Force |accessdate=September 18, 2009}} As of November 2012, modafinil is the only drug approved by the Air Force as a "go pill" for fatigue management.[http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/afsoc/publication/afsoci48-101/afsoci48-101.pdf Air Force Special Operations Command Instruction 48–101] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140611124025/http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/afsoc/publication/afsoci48-101/afsoci48-101.pdf |date=2014-06-11 }} (sects. 1.7.4), U.S. Air Force Special Operations Command, November 30, 2012. The use of [[dextroamphetamine]] (a.k.a., Dexedrine) is no longer approved. || {{yes}}{{cite web|title=Super Soldiers? Military Drug New Rage|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/Health/story?id=3408266|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=7 December 2008}} ||{{Ya|text=Confirmed testing}}|| {{yes}}{{cite web|title=IAF pilots pop pills to get fighting edge - Times of India|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/IAF-pilots-pop-pills-to-get-fighting-edge/articleshow/50894363.cms|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=5 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Indian Air Force pilots popping pills to 'heighten alertness'|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1238171|publisher=DAWN|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=8 February 2016}} ||{{unknown}} ||{{Yes}}{{cite web|title=UK army tested 'stay awake' pills|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_politics/6083840.stm|publisher=BBC NEWS|accessdate=5 January 2017}}||{{yes}}{{cite web|title=Medicine developed for Chinese Army to fight sleep|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/10/182_96829.html|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=17 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=Stay Awake, Comrades|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/impromptu-man/201204/stay-awake-comrades|publisher=Psychology Today|accessdate=5 January 2017}}||{{unknown}} |- |[[Night Eagle (drug)|Night Eagle]]|| || {{unknown}} ||{{Ya|text=Confirmed development}}{{cite web|title=PLA eyes 'Night Eagle' to make army of night owls|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/982075/pla-eyes-night-eagle-make-army-night-owls|publisher=South China Morning Post|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=16 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=China Reform Monitor - No. 928|url=http://www.afpc.org/publication_listings/viewBulletin/1280|publisher=American Foreign Policy Council|accessdate=5 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Brain Doping: A Quiet Revolution|url=http://www.asianscientist.com/2012/10/features/brain-doping-a-quiet-revolution-2012/|publisher=Asian Scientist Magazine|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=1 October 2012}}{{cite web|title=Re: [EastAsia] [OS] CHINA/CT/MIL - Chinese army develops drug to keep soldiers awake for up to 72 hours - paper|url=https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/41/4117167_re-eastasia-os-china-ct-mil-chinese-army-develops-drug-to.html|publisher=WikiLeaks|accessdate=5 January 2017}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}} |- |[[Sleeping pill]]s
(generally)|| || {{yes|See [[no-go pills]]}}{{cite web|title=This is Your Military on Drugs|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/112269/112269|publisher=New Republic|accessdate=5 January 2017|date=5 February 2013}} ||{{unknown}}||{{yes}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}}||{{unknown}} |} ==Historic== * [[Benzedrine]] was claimed to have been administered by [[Allied forces]] during [[WWII]], esp. by the US{{cite journal | author=Rasmussen N | title=Making the first anti-depressant: amphetamine in American medicine, 1929–1950 | journal=J. Hist. Med. Allied Sci.|volume=61|issue=3|pages=288–323|date=July 2006|pmid=16492800|doi=10.1093/jhmas/jrj039}} **Germany and Japan used methamphetamine.{{cite news|title=WW II German soldiers, civilians dropped amphetamines to give them boost to battle allies|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/ww-ii-german-soldiers-civilians-dropped-amphetamines-give-boost-battle-allies-article-1.1362017|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=5 January 2017}} * [[Panzerschokolade]] (Methamphetamine) during [[WWII]] by Nazi Germany{{cite web|title=Soldiers Have Used Drugs to Enhance Their Killing Capabilities in Basically Every War|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/drugs-have-been-used-in-pretty-much-every-war-ever-shooting-up|website=Vice|accessdate=5 January 2017|language=en-us}}{{cite news|last1=Ulrich|first1=Andreas|title=The Nazi Death Machine: Hitler's Drugged Soldiers|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/the-nazi-death-machine-hitler-s-drugged-soldiers-a-354606.html|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=5 January 2017}} **[[:de:Fliegerschokolade]] was the eponymous name that the [[Luftwaffe]] are claimed to have used. * In WWII, cocaine was considered for inclusion as an ingredient of a future generation of "pep pills" code named [[D-IX]] for the German military.{{cite web|url=http://amphetamines.com/nazidrug.html |title=Jeevan Vasagar: cocaine-based "wonder drug" tested on concentration camp inmates |publisher=Amphetamines.com |date=19 November 2002 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} ==See also== * {{sectionlink|History and culture of substituted amphetamines|Military use}} * [[Project MKUltra]] * [[Military medicine]] * [[Neuroenhancement]] * [[Nootropic]] * [[Supersoldier]] * [[Psychochemical warfare]] * [[Academy of Military Medical Sciences]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{cite web|last1=Sample|first1=Ian|title=US military successfully tests electrical brain stimulation to enhance staff skills|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/nov/07/us-military-successfully-tests-electrical-brain-stimulation-to-enhance-staff-skills|publisher=The Guardian}} * {{cite web|last1=Saletan|first1=William|title=The War on Sleep|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/superman/2013/05/sleep_deprivation_in_the_military_modafinil_and_the_arms_race_for_soldiers.html|publisher=Slate}} * {{cite web|last1=Glain|first1=Stephen J.|title=Israeli Biotech Firm Develops DrugThat May Limit Effects of Nerve Gas|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB906945474356077000|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=28 September 1998}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLvGftmpO5Y Presentation of the "Night Eagle" drug] on [[China Central Television]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Military drugs}} [[Category:Drugs and the military|*]] [[Category:Military comparisons|Drugs used by militaries]] [[Category:Drug-related lists]]

revision.text:
'''MakeIndex''' is a computer program which provides a sorted [[index (publishing)|index]] from unsorted raw data. MakeIndex can process raw data output by various programs, however, it is generally used with [[LaTeX]] and [[troff]].
MakeIndex was written around the year 1986 by [[Pehong Chen]] in the [[C (programming language)|C programming language]] and is [[free software]]. Six pages of documentation titled "MakeIndex: An Index Processor for LaTeX" by [[Leslie Lamport]] are available on the web and dated "17 February 1987."
== See also == *[[xindy]]
== References ==
* Wikibooks: ''[[Wikibooks:LaTeX/Indexing|LaTeX/Indexing]]'' * Pehong Chen and Michael A. Harrison: ''[http://mirror.ctan.org/indexing/makeindex/paper/ind.pdf Index preparation and processing]'' (distributed with MakeIndex) * [[Leslie Lamport]]: ''[http://tex.loria.fr/bibdex/makeindex.pdf MakeIndex: an index processor for LaTeX]'' * [[Frank Mittelbach]] et al., ''The LaTeX Companion, Addison-Wesley Professional, 2nd edition'', 2004, {{ISBN|0-201-36299-6}}
[[Category:Free software programmed in C]] [[Category:Free TeX software]] [[Category:Troff]] [[Category:Index (publishing)]]

{{one source|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Maurin Quina | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | artist = [[Leonetto Cappiello]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | city = | museum = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }} [[File:Maurin Quina.svg|thumb|250px|right]] '''''Maurin Quina''''' is a [[France|French]] [[apéritif]] advertisement painted by [[Leonetto Cappiello]] in 1906.<ref name="au"/> It is perhaps Cappiello's most famous poster.<ref name="au">National Gallery of Australia. [http://cs.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=144322 "Maurin Quina."]</ref>
The image features a devilish figure sneakily de-corking the bottle; Cappiello used "infernal imagery" in several of his posters for alcohol.<ref name="au"/> The green devil in particular evokes ''la fée verte'' (the green fairy), the nickname for [[absinthe]], a drink popular during the [[Belle Époque]].<ref name="au"/> The product was banned by the French government shortly after it was released. This poster, however, is an advertisement for an alcoholic beverage that went out of production in 1906. Maurin is the brand name and Quina is the type of alcohol. The product has since been reintroduced to both the French and American marketplace, featuring Cappiello's poster as the label. It is cherry in flavor with a background of quinine. It is similar to a liqueur, but does not contain enough sugar content to legally be classified as one.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Advertisements]]
{{advertising-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:MegatheriumClub.jpg|right| thumb|250px| Members of the Megatherium Club, circa 1855.]]
The '''Megatherium Club''' was founded by [[William Stimpson]]. It was a group of [[Washington, D.C.]]-based scientists who were attracted to that city by the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s rapidly growing collection, from 1857 to 1866.
Many of the members had no formal education, but came by their expertise through extensive direct observation. They spent their weekdays in the rigorous and exacting work of describing and classifying species. But their nights were spent in revelry.<ref name=si-club>{{cite web | url=http://www.150.si.edu/chap3/club.htm | publisher=Smithsonian Institution | title=The Megatherium Club}}</ref> They particularly enjoyed partaking in [[ale]], [[oyster]]s, [[eggnog]], and whatever other fineries their meager budgets could afford.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.si.edu/#highlightDetail/15/highlightId=648|title=Partying like it's 1855|last=|first=|date=|website=Smithsonian Institution Mobile Website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 April 2017}}</ref> On Sundays, however, they recuperated from the week's stresses and excesses with long nature [[hiking|hike]]s.
The club was named for the ''[[Megatherium]]'', an extinct genus of [[giant ground sloth]].
The leading spirit of the club was marine biologist [[William Stimpson]], who hosted its earliest meetings in his home. Members dubbed the place "The Stimpsonian."<ref name=si-club /> By 1863, though, Stimpson and others had taken up residence in the castle of the actual Smithsonian.<ref name=si-club />
Club members were encouraged by [[Spencer Fullerton Baird]], the institution's assistant secretary. And they attracted a variety of learned speakers to their meetings, including [[Louis Agassiz]], [[John Torrey]], and [[John Cassin]]. But they were eventually thrown out of their castle suites by the institution's secretary, [[Joseph Henry]], who disapproved of the way members held [[sack race]]s in the Great Hall and periodically [[serenade|serenaded]] his daughters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.si.edu/#highlightDetail/15/highlightId=648|title=Partying like it's 1855|last=|first=|date=|website=Smithsonian Institution Mobile Website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 April 2017}}</ref>
Membership was transitory as individuals undertook independent studies abroad, sometimes for years at a time. Formal meetings ceased about the year 1866 when Stimpson moved to [[Chicago]] to oversee that city's [[Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum|Academy of Sciences]].
Several other "Megatherium Clubs" exist; one formed of overseas Smithsonian researchers, yet another only in fiction, supposedly located in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].
==Members==<!--alphabetical list--> *[[Henry Bryant (naturalist)|Henry Bryant]] *James E. Cooper, owner and manager of the [[Adam Forepaugh]] Circus, donated the [[Dunk (elephant) |elephant named Dunk]] to the National Zoo in 1891. *[[Edward Drinker Cope]] *[[Lawrence Humphrey Evers]] *[[Theodore Gill]] *[[Ferdinand Hayden]] *[[Robert Kennicott]] *[[Fielding Bradford Meek]] *[[John Strong Newberry]] *[[William Stimpson]] *[[Henry Ulke]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.nmnh.si.edu/naa/siasc/si_archives.htm | publisher=Smithsonian Institution | title=A photo of four members of the Club including Stimpson}} * Spencer Fullerton Baird A Biography, Including Selections from His Writings By William Healey Dall, 1915, J.B. Lippincott, pages 231-233 for Megatherium Club
[[Category:American scientific societies]] [[Category:Defunct organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Biology societies]]

revision.text:
{{lowercase|phpLDAPadmin}} {{Infobox software | name = phpLDAPadmin | author = David Smith | developer = Deon George<ref name=deon>{{cite web|url=http://osdir.com/ml/ldap.davedap/2005-02/msg00007.html|title=New phpLDAPadmin maintainer: Deon George - msg#00007|year=2005|publisher=phpldapadmin developers mailing list}}</ref> | released = {{start date|2003}} | discontinued = yes | latest release version = 1.2.3 | latest release date = {{start date and age|2012|10|1}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | programming language = [[PHP]] | language = Catalan, Chinese (simplified), Dutch, English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Polish, Portuguese (Brazilian), Russian, Spanish and Swedish<ref name=trans>{{cite web|url=http://phpldapadmin.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Credits#Translators|title=Credits - phpLDAPadmin|publisher=phpldapadmin.sourceforge.net|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref> | genre = LDAP administration | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] | website = {{URL|phpldapadmin.sf.net}} | repo = {{URL|github.com/leenooks/phpLDAPadmin}} }} '''phpLDAPadmin''' is a [[web app]] for administering [[Lightweight Directory Access Protocol]] (LDAP) servers.<ref name=unleashed>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hG_bhCL4tQ8C&pg=PA574|title=Ubuntu Unleashed, 2012 Edition|last1=Helmke |first1=Matthew |isbn=978-0672335785|page=574|publisher=[[SAMS Publishing]]|year=2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linux.com/learn/tutorials/377952:manage-ldap-data-with-phpldapadmin|title=Making LDAP Easy on Linux with phpLDAPadmin|work=[[Linux.com]]|date=2010-11-08}}</ref> It's written in the [[PHP]] programming language, and is licensed under the [[GNU General Public License]]. The application is available in 14 languages<ref name=trans/> and supports [[UTF-8]] encoded directory strings.
==History== The project began in Fall of 2002 when Dave Smith, a student from [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU) and lead developer, needed a robust web application to manage his LDAP servers. Originally, phpLDAPadmin was called DaveDAP, but in August 2003, the name was changed to phpLDAPadmin. Since that time, the software has been downloaded approximately 150 times per day, and is commonly used throughout the world. Two other developers have contributed to the code base: Xavier Renard and Uwe Ebel. Xavier has focused on [[LDAP Data Interchange Format|LDIF]] imports/exports and [[Samba software]] integration. Uwe has focused on internationalizing the application.
In Spring of 2005, Deon George took over maintenance of phpLDAPadmin.<ref name=deon/>
No new pull requests have been merged into the master project since 2016<ref>https://github.com/leenooks/phpLDAPadmin/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed</ref>, and no further releases made. The product is no longer compatible with the recent versions of PHP and has effectively become [[abandonware]].
==Distributions== The following [[Linux distributions]] include phpLDAPadmin in their official [[software repository|software repositories]]: * [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]<ref name=unleashed/><ref name="launchpad">{{cite web|url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/phpldapadmin/|title=phpldapadmin package : Ubuntu|publisher=launchpad.net|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref> * [[Debian]]<ref name="debian">{{cite web|url=http://packages.qa.debian.org/p/phpldapadmin.html|title=Debian Package Tracking System - phpldapadmin|publisher=packages.qa.debian.org|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref> * [[Gentoo Linux]]<ref name="gentoo">{{cite web|url=http://packages.gentoo.org/package/net-nds/phpldapadmin|title=net-nds/phpldapadmin – Gentoo Packages|publisher=packages.gentoo.org|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref>
It is available in the Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux (EPEL) repository,<ref name="fedoraproject">{{cite web|url=http://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/6/x86_64/|title=Index of /pub/epel/6/x86_64|publisher=dl.fedoraproject.org|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref> allowing managed installation to distributions such as [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]], [[CentOS]] and [[Scientific Linux]], and is included in the [[M23 software distribution system]], which manages and distributes software for the Debian, Ubuntu, [[Kubuntu]], [[Xubuntu]], [[Linux Mint]], Fedora, CentOS and [[openSUSE]] distributions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartitsm.org/it_stack/m23|title=m23|publisher=smartITSM}}</ref>
It is also available in repositories for [[FreeBSD]],<ref name="freebsd">{{cite web|url=http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/ports.cgi?query=phpldapadmin|title=FreeBSD Ports Search|publisher=freebsd.org|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref><ref name=building>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0yOzQrMYLJQC&pg=PA153|title=Building A Server with FreeBSD 7: A Modular Approach|last1=Hong |first1=Bryan |isbn=978-1593271459|pages=153–156|publisher=[[No Starch Press]]|year=2008}}</ref> [[OpenBSD]],<ref name="openports">{{cite web|url=http://openports.se/www/phpldapadmin|title=OpenPorts.se | The OpenBSD package collection|publisher=openports.se|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref> and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]].<ref name="opencsw">{{cite web|url=http://www.opencsw.org/packages/phpldapadmin/|title=phpldapadmin - Solaris package|publisher=opencsw.org|accessdate=2016-07-23}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website}}

GTAby [[Seymour I. Schwartz|Seymour Schwartz, MD]]. The first edition was published in 1969 by the [[McGraw-Hill]]. It is in tenth edition in 2014. It is one of the main textbooks for medical students{{says who?|date=October 2015}} and junior surgical residents.
== Contents == Its ninth edition has 48 chapters. {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| #Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education Core Competences #Systemic Response to Injury and Metabolic Support #Fluid and Electrolyte Management of the Surgical Patient #Hemostasis, Surgical Bleeding and Transfusion #Shock #Surgical Infection #Trauma #Burns #Wound Healing #Oncology #Transplantation #Patient Safety #Physiologic Monitoring of the Surgical Patient #Minimally Invasive Surgery, Robotics, and Natural Office Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery #Molecular and Genomic Surgery #The Skin and Subcutaneous Tissue #The Breast #Disorders of the Head and Neck #Chest Wall, Lung, Mediastinum, and Pleura #Congenital Heart Disease #Acquired Heart Disease #Thoracic Aneurysms and Aortic Dissection #Arterial Disease #Venous and Lymphatic Disease #Esophagus and Diaphragmatic Hernia #Stomach #The Surgical Management of Obesity #Small Intestine #Colon, Rectum, and Anus #The Appendix #Liver #Gallbladder and the Extrahepatic Biliary System #Pancreas #Spleen #Abdominal Wall, Omentum, Mesentery, and Retroperitoneum #Soft Tissue Sarcomas #Inguinal Hernias #Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal #Pediatric Surgery #Urology #Gynecology #Neurosurgery #Orthopedic Surgery #Surgery of the Hand and Wrist #Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery #Surgical Considerations in the Elderly #Anesthesia of the Surgical Patient #Ethics, Palliative Care, and Care at the End of Life }}
== External links == * [http://accessmedicine.com/resourceTOC.aspx?resourceID=50 Access Medicine from McGraw-Hill]

'''Screenonline''' is a [[website]] about the history of [[British film]], [[British television|television]] and [[social history]] as documented by film and television. The project has been developed by the [[British Film Institute]] and funded by a £1.2 million grant from the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] [[New Opportunities Fund]].
Reviews featured on the site are usually of significant film or television topics, including production companies, films and television programmes. The site also offers downloads of clips or full episodes of television programmes, although these are only viewable in registered libraries and educational institutions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/help/register.html |title=Official FAQ |publisher=British Film Institute |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.screenonline.org.uk|Screenonline}} – official site *[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/help/index.html Screenonline help] – official FAQ

revision.text:
{{Taxobox | name = Spotback skate | image = Atlantoraja castelnaui(MIRANDA RIBEIRO,1907).jpg | status = EN | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN>{{cite journal | author = Hozbor, N. | author2 = Massa, A. | author3 = Vooren, C.M. | title = ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' | journal = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume= 2004 | page = e.T44575A10921544 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | year = 2004 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2004.RLTS.T44575A10921544.en | accessdate = 13 January 2017}}</ref> | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Chondrichthyes]] | ordo = [[Rajiformes]] | familia = [[Rajidae]] | genus = ''[[Atlantoraja]]'' | species = '''''A. castelnaui''''' | binomial = ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' | binomial_authority = ([[Alípio de Miranda-Ribeiro|A. Miranda-Ribeiro]], 1907) | synonyms = }}
The '''spotback skate''' (''Atlantoraja castelnaui'') is a species of [[fish]] in the [[Rajidae]] family. It is found off the Atlantic coasts of [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], and [[Uruguay]] where its natural [[habitat]] is over the continental shelf in the open [[sea]]. It is a large fish, growing to over a metre in length. It feeds mainly on other fish according to availability, with shrimps, octopuses and other invertebrates also being eaten. Reproduction takes place throughout most of the year, with the eggs being laid in capsules that adhere to the seabed. The spotback skate is the subject of a fishery and is thought to be overfished, resulting in [[Greenpeace]] adding the fish to its red list of fish to be avoided, and the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] listing it as an "[[endangered species]]".
== Distribution == The ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' are found in the Southwest South Atlantic Ocean from Rio de Janeiro State in Brazil to Argentina. They prefer warm-temperate waters at depths ranging from 20 to 220 m.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://journal.nafo.int/38/oddone/5-oddone.pdf|title = Length-weight relationships, condition and population structure of the genus ''Atlantoraja'' (Elasmobranchii, Rajidae, Arhynchobatinae) in Southeastern Brazilian waters, SW Atlantic Ocean|last = Oddone|first = Maria Cristine|date = 2015-10-28|journal = Journal of Northwest Atlantic Fishery Science |volume=38 |pages=43–52 |doi = |pmid = |access-date = 29 October 2015}}</ref> In Argentina, they can be found as natives to the Argentinian Zoogeographic Province. They seek warm water climates, and are often reported to have a more southern distribution than normal in correlation with higher water temperatures. Spotback skates may migrate only slightly or perform slight periodic backwards and forwards movement depending on ocean water temperatures.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bovcon|first1=N. D.|last2=Cochia|first2=P. D.|last3=Góngora|first3=M. E.|last4=Gosztonyi|first4=A. E.|title=New records of warm-temperate water fishes in central Patagonian coastal waters (Southwestern South Atlantic Ocean) |journal=Journal of Applied Ichthyology |date=2011 |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=832–839 |doi=10.1111/j.1439-0426.2010.01594.x}}</ref> However, there is no notable seasonal variation for the species as they populate southern waters year round.
Although the location of their distribution has not been affected, the quantity of the spotback's distribution has lowered in many places and continues to be threatened by humans fishing in its habitats.<ref name=":2" />
== Reproduction == The length of maturity for males and females differ with males ranging from 185 to 1250 mm in total length and females ranging from 243 to 1368 mm in total length.<ref name=":0" /> Males have a continuous production of mature spermatozoa suggests they can reproduce throughout the year but studies have shown higher values in certain months but they are not significant. Females also reproduce year-round with peaks of reproductive activity as well.<ref name=":0" />
Female spotback skates lay their eggs on the ocean floor and leave them there. There is not parental care so the eggs have a capsule that protects the embryo's development once the mother leaves.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1679-87592008000100007&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en|title = Description of the egg capsule of ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' (Elasmobranchii, Rajidae)|last = Oddone|first = Maria C.|date = 2008|journal = Brazilian Journal of Oceanography |doi = 10.1590/S1679-87592008000100007|pmid = |access-date = 29 October 2015|volume = 56|issue = 1|pages = 65–68}}</ref> Collected egg capsules typically are rectangular and have horny process in each corner. They are also shiny and are medium brown in color.<ref name=":3" /> The capsules on the eggs are covered by adhesion fibrils that allow the egg to attach itself to the sea floor immediately after the mother releases them. These adhesion fibrils are also seen in other species of skates.<ref name=":3" /> The surface of the capsule is striated and presents a rough surface though it is relatively smooth. ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' capsule's are also the largest egg capsule in its genus and compared to other co-occurring species in the same area and depth of the ocean.<ref name=":3" />
== Conservation status == In the cities of Santos and Guarujá, specimens of the spotback skate which are deemed large enough to have commercial value are commonly landed and marketed.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Oddone|first1=María C.|last2=Amorim|first2=Alberto F.|last3=Mancini|first3=Patricia L.|title=Reproductive biology of the spotback skate, ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' (Ribeiro, 1907) (Chondrichthyes, Rajidae), in southeastern Brazilian waters|journal=Revista de Biología Marina y Oceanografía|date=2008|volume=43|issue=2|pages=327–334|url=http://www.scielo.cl/pdf/revbiolmar/v43n2/art10.pdf}}</ref> From 1999 to present, the market for the meat of the spotback skate has expanded to Asia, particularly South Korea.<ref name=":0" /> As a result, commercial fishing has led to an overexploitation of the species and its consequent listing as an endangered species.
Spotback skates are particularly vulnerable to extinction<ref name=":5" /> due to their large body size relative to other skate species. According to Dulvy & Reynolds (2002), skate species considered to be locally extinct have larger body sizes compared to all other skates.<ref name=":0" /> Large body size is in turn correlated with higher mortality rates and with life-history parameters such as late age at maturity.<ref name=":0" /> Another study by García et al. (2007) also corroborated the notion that a large body size increased the extinction risk in elasmobranchs.<ref name=":0" /> Spotback skates are also especially vulnerable to trawl fisheries because they inhabit the soft bottom substrates of the ocean (Ebert; Sulikowski, 2007).<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Size and sex composition of two species of the genus ''Atlantoraja'' (Elasmobranchii, Rajidae) caught by the bottom trawl fisheries operating on the Uruguayan continental shelf (southwestern Atlantic Ocean)|url = http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_abstract&pid=S1679-87592011000400006&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en|journal = Brazilian Journal of Oceanography |pages = 357–364|volume = 59|issue = 4|doi = 10.1590/S1679-87592011000400006|first = Luis|last = Orlando|first2 = Ines|last2 = Pereyra|first3 = Laura|last3 = Paesch|first4 = Walter|last4 = Norbis}}</ref> Consequently, the biomass of spotback skates has decreased by 75% from 1994 to 1999.<ref name=IUCN/><ref name=":1" />
== Behavior and eating habits == The spotback skate is found across most of the continental shelf year round.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal|last1=Barbini|first1=Santiago A.|last2=Lucifora|first2=Luis O.|title=Feeding habits of a large endangered skate from the south-west Atlantic: the spotback skate, ''Atlantoraja castelnaui'' |journal=Marine and Freshwater Research |date=2012|volume=63 |issue=2 |pages=180–188 |doi=10.1071/MF11170 |url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/256840973_Feeding_habits_of_a_large_endangered_skate_from_the_Southwest_Atlantic_the_spotback_skate_Atlantoraja_castelnaui}}</ref> The spotback skate's diet is a versatile and mainly piscivorous consumer. Their diet shifts with increasing body size and as a response to seasonal and regional changes in prey abundance and distribution. They prey mostly on teleost, cephalopods, elasmobranchs, and decapods. Smaller spotback skate tend to consume decapods and the larger skates ate elasmobranchs and cephalopods.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Effects of intrinsic and extrinsic factors on the diet of ''Bathyraja macloviana'', a benthophagous skate|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jfb.12159/abstract|journal = Journal of Fish Biology|date = 2013-07-01|issn = 1095-8649|pages = 156–169|volume = 83|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/jfb.12159|first = S. A.|last = Barbini|first2 = L. B.|last2 = Scenna|first3 = D. E.|last3 = Figueroa|first4 = J. M.|last4 = Díaz de Astarloa}}</ref> The consumption of teleosts differed between seasons depending on whether the teleost were demersal- benthic or benthic. The more demersal- benthic teleosts were consumed during the cold season while the benthic teleosts were eaten during the warm season.<ref name=":4" /> The decapods, cephalopods and elasmobranchs were predominantly shrimps, octopuses, and skates. The main cephalopod consumed in the warm season was the octopus.<ref name=":1" /> == Parasites == [[File:Parasite180057-fig2 Chloromyxum atlantoraji drawing.png|thumb|left|''Chloromyxum atlantoraji'', a [[Myxozoa]]n parasite of spotback skates in [[Argentina]]]] Like all fish species, spotback skates have a variety of [[fish_parasites|parasites]]; these include [[copepod]]s <ref name="IrigoitiaCantatore2016">{{cite journal|last1=Irigoitia|first1=Manuel M.|last2=Cantatore|first2=Delfina M.P.|last3=Incorvaia|first3=Inés S.|last4=Timi|first4=Juan T.|title=Parasitic copepods infesting the olfactory sacs of skates from the southwestern Atlantic with the description of a new species of ''Kroeyerina'' Wilson, 1932|journal=Zootaxa|volume=4174|issue=1|year=2016|pages=137|issn=1175-5334|doi=10.11646/zootaxa.4174.1.10}}</ref>, [[nematodes]] <ref name="IrigoitiaBraicovich2018">{{cite journal|last1=Irigoitia|first1=Manuel Marcial|last2=Braicovich|first2=Paola Elizabeth|last3=Lanfranchi|first3=Ana Laura|last4=Farber|first4=Marisa Diana|last5=Timi|first5=Juan Tomás|title=Distribution of anisakid nematodes parasitizing rajiform skates under commercial exploitation in the Southwestern Atlantic|journal=International Journal of Food Microbiology|volume=267|year=2018|pages=20–28|issn=01681605|doi=10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2017.12.009}}</ref> and [[Myxozoa]]ns.<ref name="CantatoreIrigoitia2018">{{cite journal|last1=Cantatore|first1=Delfina María Paula|last2=Irigoitia|first2=Manuel Marcial|last3=Holzer|first3=Astrid Sibylle|last4=Bartošová-Sojková|first4=Pavla|last5=Pecková|first5=Hana|last6=Fiala|first6=Ivan|last7=Timi|first7=Juan Tomás|title=The description of two new species of ''Chloromyxum'' from skates in the Argentine Sea reveals that a limited geographic host distribution causes phylogenetic lineage separation of myxozoans in Chondrichthyes|journal=Parasite|volume=25|year=2018|pages=47|issn=1776-1042|doi=10.1051/parasite/2018051|url=https://www.parasite-journal.org/articles/parasite/full_html/2018/01/parasite180057/parasite180057.html|PMID= 30207267}} {{open access}}</ref>
== Sustainable consumption == In 2010, Greenpeace International has added the spotback skate to its seafood red list. "The Greenpeace International seafood red list is a list of fish that are commonly sold in supermarkets around the world, and which have a very high risk of being sourced from unsustainable fisheries."<ref>[http://www.greenpeace.org/international/seafood/red-list-of-species Greenpeace International Seafood Red list]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Taxonbar|from=Q3753745}}
[[Category:Atlantoraja]] [[Category:Fish described in 1907]] [[Category:Fish of the Atlantic Ocean]] [[Category:Seafood red list]] [[Category:Taxonomy articles created by Polbot]] [[Category:Taxa named by Alípio de Miranda-Ribeiro]]

[[Image:theaetetus stephanus page142.jpg|thumb|Volume 1, Page 142 of the 1578 Stephanus edition of Plato, showing the opening of ''Theaetetus'']]
'''Stephanus pagination''' is a system of reference and organization used in modern editions and translations of [[Plato]] (and less famously, [[Plutarch]]) based on the three volume 1578 edition<ref>''Platonis opera quae extant omnia'' edidit Henricus Stephanus, Genevae, 1578.</ref> of Plato's complete works translated by Joannes Serranus ([[Jean de Serres]]) and published by Henricus Stephanus ([[Henri Estienne]]) in [[Geneva]].
==Overview== In the case of Plato's works, Stephanus pagination first divides the works into numbers that are the page numbers of each of the Stephanus edition's three volumes, and each such page and page number is further subdivided into lettered sections which correspond to parallel Greek/Latin translated passages on a given page, mostly commonly a, b, c, d, and e. This system is used in modern scholarship to cite Plato. For Plato's works, unique coordinates for a passage can therefore be given with three pieces of information: the work's name, the (Stephanus) page number, and the letter denoting the passage. For example, "''Symposium'' 172a" cites ''[[Symposium (Plato)|Symposium]]'', Stephanus page 172 (the volume in which ''Symposium'' occurs, as it happens, volume 3), passage a. To avoid ambiguity in this scheme, either the Platonic work or the volume must be cited; absent this, "page 50" might refer to any of the "pages 50" across Stephanus' three volumes. Reference to Stephanus manifestly presupposes the existing ordering of the work in its given volumes, but given historical disagreement as to the chronology and proper ordering of Plato's works, care should therefore be taken when referring to Stephanus pagination as opposed to another scheme.
More specific citations may add line numbers, e.g. ''Symposium'' 209a5–9, but these generally refer to the lines in [[John Burnet (classicist)|John Burnet]]'s [[Oxford Classical Text]], not to Estienne's line divisions.
There are some peculiarities in the Stephanus page numbers. The length of each page and each paragraph can vary if extra commentary appears on the page of the 1578 edition. Thus Stephanus pages are not all of the same length. Some pages do not have all the paragraphs a through e. There are also gaps in the sequence of Stephanus page numbers for Plato's ''[[Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' and ''[[Laws (dialogue)|Laws]]''. The reason is that the editors added separate introductions to each 'book' of these longer works, and thus the page numbers of these introductions are not used to refer to pages in Plato's dialogues.
The spurious dialogue ''[[Halcyon (dialogue)|Halcyon]]'' was included in the corpus of [[Lucian]]'s works and does not have Stephanus numbers.
[[Bekker numbering]] is the comparable system for the works of [[Aristotle]], and [[Diels–Kranz numbering]] is the comparable system for [[Pre-Socratic philosophy]]. Unlike Stephanus pagination, Bekker numbering starts with page 1 and proceeds through all of Aristotle's works without starting over, regardless of the number of volumes needed for a given edition. Bekker numbering therefore has the advantage, not shared by Stephanus pagination, of giving compact, unambiguous numerical citation of a given passage, page, etc, without the absolute necessity in order to avoid ambiguity to specify the dialogue, work or volume which exists in the case of Stephanus.
==Stephanus numbers==
===Volume 1=== * (2a–16a) ''[[Euthyphro]]'' * (17a–42a) ''[[Apology (Plato)|Apologia Socratis]]'' * (43a–54e) ''[[Crito]]'' * (57a–118a) ''[[Phaedo]]'' * (121a–131a) ''[[Theages]]'' * (132a–139a) ''[[Rival Lovers|Amatores]]'' * (142a–210d) ''[[Theaetetus (dialogue)|Theaetetus]]'' * (216a–268b) ''[[Sophist (dialogue)|Sophista]]'' * (271a–307c) ''[[Euthydemus (dialogue)|Euthydemus]]'' * (309a–362a) ''[[Protagoras (dialogue)|Protagoras]]'' * (363a–376c) ''[[Hippias Minor]]'' * (383a–440e) ''[[Cratylus (dialogue)|Cratylus]]'' * (447a–527e) ''[[Gorgias (dialogue)|Gorgias]]'' * (530a–542b) ''[[Ion (dialogue)|Ion]]''
===Volume 2=== * (11a–67b) ''[[Philebus]]'' * (70a–100b) ''[[Meno]]'' * (103a–135e) ''[[First Alcibiades|Alcibiades I]]'' * (138a–151c) ''[[Second Alcibiades|Alcibiades II]]'' * (153a–176d) ''[[Charmides (dialogue)|Charmides]]'' * (178a–201c) ''[[Laches (dialogue)|Laches]]'' * (203a–223b) ''[[Lysis (dialogue)|Lysis]]'' * (225a–232c) ''[[Hipparchus (dialogue)|Hipparchus]]'' * (234a–249e) ''[[Menexenus (dialogue)|Menexenus]]'' * (257a–311c) ''[[Statesman (dialogue)|Politicus]]'' * (313a–321d) ''[[Minos (dialogue)|Minos]]'' * ''[[Republic (dialogue)|Respublica]]'' :* (327a–354c) ''Respublica'' I :* (357a–383c) ''Respublica'' II :* (386a–417b) ''Respublica'' III :* (419a–445e) ''Respublica'' IV :* (449a–480a) ''Respublica'' V :* (484a–511e) ''Respublica'' VI :* (514a–541b) ''Respublica'' VII :* (543a–569c) ''Respublica'' VIII :* (571a–592b) ''Respublica'' IX :* (595a–621d) ''Respublica'' X * ''[[Laws (dialogue)|Leges]]'' :* (624a–650b) ''Leges'' I :* (652a–674c) ''Leges'' II :* (676a–702e) ''Leges'' III :* (704a–724b) ''Leges'' IV :* (726a–747e) ''Leges'' V :* (751a–785b) ''Leges'' VI :* (788a–824a) ''Leges'' VII :* (828a–850c) ''Leges'' VIII :* (853a–882c) ''Leges'' IX :* (884a–910d) ''Leges'' X :* (913a–938c) ''Leges'' XI :* (941a–969d) ''Leges'' XII * (973a–992e) ''[[Epinomis]]''
===Volume 3=== [[Image:Timaeus stephanus pages 32 33.jpg|thumb|400px|Volume 3, pages 32–33, of the 1578 Stephanus edition of Plato, showing a passage of ''Timaeus'' with the Latin translation and notes of [[Jean de Serres]]]] * (17a–92c) ''[[Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]]'' * (106a–121c) ''[[Critias (dialogue)|Critias]]'' * (126a–166c) ''[[Parmenides (dialogue)|Parmenides]]'' * (172a–223d) ''[[Symposium (Plato dialogue)|Symposium]]'' * (227a–279c) ''[[Phaedrus (dialogue)|Phaedrus]]'' * (281a–304e) ''[[Hippias Major]]'' * (309a–363e) ''[[Epistles (Plato)|Epistolae]]'' ** (309a–310b) [[First Letter (Plato)|Epistola I]] ** (310b–315a) [[Second Letter (Plato)|Epistola II]] ** (315a–319e) [[Third Letter (Plato)|Epistola III]] ** (320a–321c) [[Fourth Letter (Plato)|Epistola IV]] ** (321c–322c) [[Fifth Letter (Plato)|Epistola V]] ** (322c–323d) [[Sixth Letter (Plato)|Epistola VI]] ** (323d–352a) [[Seventh Letter (Plato)|Epistola VII]] ** (352b–357d) [[Eighth (Plato)|Epistola VIII]] ** (357d–358b) [[Ninth Letter (Plato)|Epistola IX]] ** (358b–358c) [[Tenth Letter (Plato)|Epistola X]] ** (358d–359c) [[Eleventh (Plato)|Epistola XI]] ** (359c–359e) [[Twelfth (Plato)|Epistola XII]] ** (360a–363e) [[Thirteenth (Plato)|Epistola XIII]] * (364a–372a) ''[[Axiochus (dialogue)|Axiochus]]'' * (372a–375d) ''[[On Justice|De Justitia]]'' * (376a–379d) ''[[On Virtue|De Virtute]]'' * (380a–386b) ''[[Demodocus (dialogue)|Demodocus]]'' * (387b–391d) ''[[Sisyphus (dialogue)|Sisyphus]]'' * (392a–406a) ''[[Eryxias (dialogue)|Eryxias]]'' * (406a–410e) ''[[Clitophon (dialogue)|Clitopho]]'' * (411a–416a) ''[[Definitions (Plato)|Definitiones]]''
==See also== * [[Bekker numbering]] * [[Diels–Kranz numbering]]
