revision.text:
[[File:SekienUshi-no-tokimairi.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Ushi no toki mairi
from the ''[[Konjaku Gazu Zoku Hyakki]]'' (1779) by [[Sekien Toriyama]]]] {{nihongo||丑の時参り|'''Ushi no toki mairi'''|lead=yes}} or {{nihongo||丑刻参り|'''ushi no koku mairi'''|extra2=lit. "ox-hour shrine-visit"}}{{Harvnb|Nelson|1996|p=143}} gives "shrine visitation at the hour of the cow" refers to a prescribed method of laying a [[curse]] upon a target that is traditional to Japan, so-called because it is conducted during the [[Chinese zodiac#hours|hours of the Ox]] (between 1 and 3 AM). The practitioner—typically a scorned woman{{Harvnb|Joly|1912|pp=41-}}—while dressed in white and crowning herself with an iron ring set with three lit candles upright, hammers nails into a sacred tree{{nihongo|sacred tree|[[:ja:御神木|神木]]|shinboku}} of the [[Shinto shrine]]. In the modern-day common conception, the nails are driven through a straw effigy{{nihongo|straw doll|[[:ja:藁人形|藁人形]]|wara ningyō}} of the victim, impaled upon the tree behind it. The ritual must be repeated seven days running, after which the curse is believed to succeed, causing death to the target, but being witnessed in the act is thought to nullify the spell.{{Harvnb|Jurgis|1997|loc=p.290 and footnote 72}} The [[Kibune Shrine]] in Kyoto is famously associated with the ritual.{{cite book|ref=harv|last1=Reader|first1=Ian|last2=Tanabe|first2=George Joji|title=Practically Religious: Worldly Benefits and the Common Religion of Japan|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|year=1998|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-8zmlaQSEIwC&pg=PA140|isbn=978-0824820909|page=140}} Also variously called {{nihongo||丑時詣|ushi no toki mōde}}, {{nihongo||丑参り|ushi mairi}}, {{nihongo||丑三参り|ushimitsu mairi}}.{{Citation|editor-last=新村|editor-first=出 (Niimura, Izuru)|title=広辞苑 (Kojien|edition=第4版|year=1991|publisher=岩波書店|isbn=978-4-00-080101-0|chapter=うしのときまいり|title-link=Kojien}}{{citation|title=日本国語大辞典 (Nihon kokugo daijiten)|volume=2|publisher=小学館|year=1972|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YBtbAAAAMAAJ|page=567}} ==Overview== Sources say that common method of the ritual developed during the [[Edo period]] (1603–1868).{{Harvnb|Nelson|1996|pp=143–144}}, citing {{cite book|last=Ono|first=Susumu (小野進)|title=古語辞典|year=1974}} The woman performing the curse is generally portrayed as dressed in white, with disheveled hair, wearing an iron "crown" that holds three burning candles, suspending (from her neck) a mirror upon her chest{{Harvnb|Mitford|1870|pp=139–140}} (which lies hidden) and wearring a pair of tall [[clogs]] (''[[Geta (footwear)|geta]]'').{{Harvnb|三橋|2011|pp=264–5}} states that she wears tall clogs with only one support board (「一本歯の高下駄」) , even though the accompanying illustration from a [[Toyohiro|Utagawa Toyohiro]] print clearly shows two supports. She would then nail a straw doll representing her target to a {{nihongo|sacred tree|[[:ja:御神木|神木]]|shimboku}} at the [[Shinto shrine]].{{Harvnb|Pfoundes|1875|pp=19–20}}, quoted in {{Harvnb|Hildburgh|1915|loc=65. Notes.. Magical Methods for Injuring Persons, p.118}} The iron "crown" that she wears is actually a {{nihongo|tripod|[[:ja:五徳|五徳]]|gotoku}} (or [[trivet]], a stand for setting cooking pots, etc., above a heat source) which she wears in inverted,{{Harvnb|Griffis|1876|p=474}} slipping the iron ring over her head and sticking candles on its three legs. [[File:A woman makes a cursing ritual ceremony.jpg|upright=1.5|thumb|A woman summoning a [[yōkai]] through ''ushi no toki mairi'', by [[Hokusai|Katsushika Hokusai]]]] It was believed that the spot struck on the straw doll corresponded to the area of the body where the target would begin to experience illness or injury. However, this straw doll or other form of effigy was not a definitive requisite in the ritual even relatively late in the Edo Period. For instance, in [[Toriyama Sekien]]'s ''[[Konjaku Gazu Zoku Hyakki]]'' (1779, pictured top right) depicts the woman holding a hammer but no doll, nor is the doll mentioned in the caption.Sekien (1779), quote: 「丑時まいりハ、胸に一ツの鏡をかくし、頭に三つの燭〔ともしび〕を點じ、 丑みつの比神社にまうでゝ杉の梢に釘うつとかや。 はかなき女の嫉妬より起りて、人を失ひ身をうしなふ。 人を呪咀〔のろわ〕ば穴二つほれとは、よき近き譬ならん」 Translation: In the ''ushi doki mairi'', [a woman] conceals a mirror in the bosom, lights three candles around her head, visits the shrine in the ''ushi mitsu'' hour (third quarter of the hour of the [[ox (zodiac)|ox]], 2:00~2:30 AM), and drives nails into a [[sugi]] tree. The fleeting jealousies of a woman, brings ruin to the person and body. It is well said the proverb "curse someone, dig a second grave [for yourself]". In this case, the nails are driven directly into the branches of the sacred tree. The props used are described somewhat differently, depending on the source. Nails of a particular size called {{nihongo||[[:ja:五寸釘|五寸釘]]|gosun kugi|extra="five inch nails"}} are prescribed according to some authorities. She may hold in her mouth a [[comb]],小松和彦(Komatsu, Kazuhiko)「いでたちは白い着物を着て、髮を乱し、顔に白粉、歯には鉄漿、口紅を濃くつくる、頭には鉄輪をかぶり、その三つの足にろうそくを立ててともす。胸に鏡を掛け、口に櫛をくわえる。履き物は歯の高い足駄である」 quoted in:{{citation|last=松井|first=吉昭|contribution=多賀社参詣曼陀羅を読む|publisher=歴研]|year=2000|format=snippet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SXY0AQAAIAAJ|isbn=978-4947769022|page=173|title=時と文化: 日本史攷究の視座 : 岡田芳朗先生古稀記念論集}} or a "torch of bamboo and pine roots lighted at both ends". The "proper witching hour" is, strictly speaking, the ''ushi no mitsu doki'' (2:00–2:30 am). In Sekien's or [[Hokusai]]'s print (above), the woman performing the curse ritual is depicted with a black ox by her side. Such a black ox, lying [[wikt:recumbent|recumbent]], is expected to appear on the seventh night of the ritual, and one must stride or straddle over the animal to complete the task to success,{{citation|editor-last=関|editor-first=一敏|editor2-last=大塚|editor2-first=和夫|title=宗教人類学入門|publisher=弘文堂|year=2004|page=149}} but if one betrays fear at the ox's apparition the "potency of the charm is lost". ==History== {{See also|Hashihime}} In earlier times, the term simply referred to worshiping at the shrine during the hours of the ox, and the curse connotation developed later. At the [[Kibune Shrine]] in [[Kyoto Prefecture|Kyoto]], there was a tradition that if one prayed here on the "ox hour of the ox day of the ox month of the [[Ox (zodiac)|ox year]]" the wish was likely to be granted, because it was during this alignment of the hour, day, month, and year that the Kibune deity was believed to have made descent upon the shrine. However, the shrine became known a cursing spot in later development.{{Harvnb|三橋|2011|pp=264–5}} The Kibune Shrine became strongly associated with the ox hour curse following the fame of the medieval legend of the [[Hashihime]] of [[Uji, Kyoto|Uji]] ("The Princess of the {{Interlanguage link multi|Uji Bridge{{!}}Bridge of Uji|2=ja|3=宇治橋|preserve=1}}"). The legend is considered the prime source of the later conception ''Ushi no toki mairi'' curse ritual.{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Marvin|first=Stephen E.|title=Heaven has a face, so does hell: the art of the Noh mask|volume=1|publisher=Floating World Editions|year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4bNJAQAAIAAJ|page=278|isbn=978-1891640322}} According to legend, Hashihime in mortal life was the daughter of a certain nobleman, but consumed by jealousy, made a wish to become a ''kijin'' (an ''[[oni]]'' demon) capable of destroying her love rival. After 7 days at Kibune Shrine, she was finally given revelation by the resident deity "to bathe for thirty seven days in the rapids of the [[Uji River]]."{{citation|last=Kato|first=Eileen|contribution=The Iron Crown (Kanawa)|editor-last=Keene|editor-first=Donald|work=Twenty Plays of the Nō Theatre|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=1970|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ea1vu0-3FiUC&pg=PA193|pages=193–194ff|title=Twenty Plays of the N? Theatre|isbn=9780231034555}} Note that even though Kibune has later been seen as a mecca for the ritual, Hashihime only learned the recipe here, and enacted it miles away (Kibune is in the north of Kyoto, the Uji River is to the south). The earliest written text of the legend occurs in a late [[Kamakura period|Kamakura-period]] variant text (''Yashirobon'' codex) of ''[[The Tale of Heike]]'', under the ''Tsurugi no maki'' ("Book of the Sword") chapter.{{citation|last=Kawashima|first=Terry|title=Writing Margins: The Textual Construction of Gender in Heian and Kamakura Japan|publisher=Harvard Univ Asia Center|year=2001|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KC807wsyLA0C&pg=PA272|pages=272–|isbn=978-0674005167}} According to it, Hashihime was originally a mortal during the reign of [[Emperor Saga]] (809 to 823), but after turning demon and killing her rival, her man's kinsmen, then indiscriminately other innocent parties, she lived on beyond the normal human life span, to prey on the samurai [[Watanabe no Tsuna]] at the {{nihongo|Ichijo Modoribashi|[[:ja:一条戻橋|一条戻橋]]|extra2="Turning Back bridge at the street crossing of Ichijō and Horikawa"}} bridge, only to have her arm severed by the sword {{nihongo|Higekiri|[[:ja:髭切|髭切]]}}. Tsuna kept the demon's arm, whose power was contained by the {{nihongo|Yinyang master|[[:ja:陰陽師|陰陽師]]|[[Onmyōdō#onmyōji|onmyōji]]}} [[Abe no Seimei]], via chanting the [[Humane King Sutra|Ninnō-kyō]] sutra.{{citation|last=Selinger|first=Vyjayanthi R.|title=Writing Margins: The Textual Construction of Gender in Heian and Kamakura Japan|publisher=BRILL|year=2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gbwdAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA130|pages=130|isbn=978-9004255333}} In this variant of the "chapter of the sword", the ceremony that the woman undergoes at the Uji River to transmogrify into the demon is described as follows:
Secluding herself in a deserted spot, she divided her long hair into five bunches and fashioned these bunches into horns. She daubed her face with vermilion and her body with cinnabar, set on her head an iron tripod with burning brands [* or "to each of its leg, a torch made with pine wood is tied and afired" in {{Harvnb|Kusano|1962|p=30}}] attached to its legs and held in her mouth another brand, burning at both ends. {{right|—From ''Tsurugi no Maki''{{citation|last=Kusano|first=Eisaburō|title=Stories behind noh and kabuki plays|publisher=Tokyo News Service|year=1962|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USm1AAAAIAAJ|page=30}}{{Harvnb|Kato|1970}}Kato, quoted in {{Harvnb|Murguia|2013}}}}
Thus in the ''Tsurugi no maki'' can be seen such elements as the wearing of the tripod (here called {{nihongo||鉄輪|kanawa}}) and propping lit torches (similar to candles in later tradition), but the woman painted her entire face and body red, rather than remain in pure white garb. Later during the [[Muromachi period]], this legend was adapted by [[Zeami Motokiyo|Zeami]] into the [[Noh]] play ''Kanawa'' or "The Iron Crown". The Noh play inherits essentially the same outfit for the principal woman, who is commanded by the oracle to "daub your face with red and wear scarlet clothing," and uses neither a straw doll or hammer, but has the yingyang master Seimei creates "two life-size straw effigies of the man and his new wife [with] their names [placed] inside" in order to perform the rites to excorcize Hashihime's demon. Therefore, the later form of the ''ushi no mairi'' developed afterwards, {{Citation needed span|date=April 2014|text=through the marriage of the use of dolls in the Japanese esoteric art of ''[[onmyōdō]]'' with the shrine visiting of the ox hour}}. === Curse using dolls in antiquity === The use of dolls in the cursing ritual has been practiced since antiquity, with a reference in the ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'' chronicle under the reign of [[Emperor Yōmei]], which relates that in the year 587, Nakatomi no Katsumi no Muraji "preparede figures of the Imperial {{Interlanguage link multi|Prince Oshisaka no Hikohito no Ōe{{!}}Prince Hikobito|2=ja|3=押坂彦人大兄皇子|preserve=1}} ... and [spellcast] them", but it did not work.{{cite book|ref=harv|author-link=William George Aston|last=Aston|first=William George|title=Nihongi: Chronicles of Japan from the Earliest Times to A.D. 697|volume=1|place=London|publisher=Japan Society of London|year=1896|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1IJrNAKBpycC&pg=PA109|page=109–}} However, this record does not clarify if the dolls were poked by sharp implements. There are unearthed [[Archeology|archeological]] relics shaped like human dolls suspected of being used in curses. Called {{nihongo|wooden purificatory figurines|木製人形代|mokusei hitogatashiro}}, some have faces realistically drawn and ink, and others with iron nails driven into the breast. One such from the 8th century is held by the [[Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties]].{{citation|last=永藤|first=靖 (Nagafuji, Yasushi)|title=古代仏教説話の方法: 霊異記から験記へ|publisher=三弥井書店 |year=2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BNcxAAAAMAAJ|pages=22}}{{cite web|last=梅屋|first=潔 (Umeya, Kiyoshi)|title=のろい (noroi)|website=日本民俗学会編『民俗学事典』丸善、近刊予定|volume=Ⅲ-④-10 および 19|format=pdf|url=http://www2.kobe-u.ac.jp/~umeya/site01/_userdata/noroi.pdf|accessdate=April 2014}} Another from the Tatechō site in [[Matsue, Shimane]], a wooden tag depicts a female figure, apparently a noblewoman deducing from attire, and this doll had three wooden pegs or nails driven into it, aiming at her breasts and her heart.{{citation|last=勝部|first=昭|others=川原和人, 宮澤明久, 柳浦俊一, 大谷祐司, 長峰康典|title=タテチョウ遺跡発掘調査報告書III|publisher=島根県教育委員会|year=1990|url=http://rar.lib.shimane-u.ac.jp/Repository/metadata/8441|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429184253/http://rar.lib.shimane-u.ac.jp/Repository/metadata/8441|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-04-29|pages=375, 377註2}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20140429190353/http://rar.lib.shimane-u.ac.jp/Repository/file/8441/20090804000000/%E3%82%BF%E3%83%86%E3%83%81%E3%83%A7%E3%82%A6%E9%81%BA%E8%B7%A1%E7%99%BA%E6%8E%98%E8%AA%BF%E6%9F%BB%E5%A0%B1%E5%91%8A%E6%9B%B8III%E6%9C%AC%E7%B7%A8(2).pdf 本編(2).pdf ] == Miscellaneous == * In Japanese law studies, attempts to commit murder through the ''ushi no mairi'' is often cited as the "textbook example of [[impossibility defense]] case crime".{{cite book|last=飯塚|first=敏夫|chapter=第六 丑の刻詣りと不能犯學說|title=刑法論攷|volume=第1巻|publisher=松華堂書店|year=1934|pages=133–142}}{{cite journal|last=沢登|first=佳人|title=許された危険の法理に基づく因果関係論の克服 (Überwindung der Kausalitätslehre durch die Lehre vom erlaubten Risiko)|journal=法政理論|volume=30|number=4|year=1998|pages=101–127 (107–111)|url=http://dspace.lib.niigata-u.ac.jp:8080/dspace/handle/10191/14905|issn=0286-1577|access-date=2014-04-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427000239/http://dspace.lib.niigata-u.ac.jp:8080/dspace/handle/10191/14905|archive-date=2014-04-27|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Popular art == * The film ''Kanawa'' (1969) is based on the noh play.{{cite book|last=McDonald|first=Keiko I. |title=Japanese Classical Theater in Films|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press|year=1994|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=itkQCisDAawC&pg=PA280|pages=272–|isbn=978-0838635025}} ==See also== *[[Shintai]] *''[[Bai sema|kekkai]]'' (結界) *[[Mitama#Ara-mitama and nigi-mitama|Ara-mitama and nigi-mitama]] *[[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] *[[Voodoo doll]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|Rinki no hi no tama|2=ja|3=悋気の火の玉|preserve=1}}, a [[Rakugo]] repertoire in which the main character's life and lover both go on ''ushi no toki mairi'' ==Footnotes== ===Explanatory notes=== {{Notelist}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} * {{citation|last=Elisonas|first=Jurgis|contribution=Notorious Places|work=Edo and Paris: Urban Life and the State in the Early Modern Era|publisher=Cornell University Press|year=1997|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-qOuykzxhKUC&pg=PA290|isbn=978-0801481833|page=290}} * {{Cite book|ref=harv|last=Griffis|first=William Elliot|title=The Mikado's Empire|publisher=Harper & Brothers|year=1876|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ld_BNvbt3MgC&pg=PA474|page=474}} ** [https://books.google.com/books?id=_S1d6ONY1vkC&pg=PA474 New Edition of 1883] * {{Cite journal|last=Hildburgh|first=W. L.|title=65. Notes on Some Japanese Magical Methods for Injuring Persons|journal=Man|volume=15|year=1915|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-NrVFdQXoukC&pg=PA116|pages=116–121|doi=10.2307/2787870|jstor=2787870}} * {{Cite journal|last=Joly|first=Hernri L.|title=Bakemono|journal=Transactions and Proceedings of the Japan Society, London|volume=9|year=1912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gCY2AQAAMAAJ|pages=41–}} * {{Cite journal|last=Mitford|first=A. B.|title=Tales of Old Japan: No. II The Loves of Gompachi and Komurasaki|journal=The Fortnightly|series=new series|volume=8|year=1870|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VfjRAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA139|pages=139–}} * {{Cite journal|last=Murguia|first=Salvador Jimenez|title=The Cursing Kit of Ushi no Koku Mairi|journal=Preternature: Critical and Historical Studies on the Preternatural|volume=2|number=1|year=2013|jstor=10.5325/preternature.2.1.0073|pages=73–91|doi=10.5325/preternature.2.1.0073}} * {{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=John K.|title=Freedom of Expression: The Very Modern Practice of Visiting a Shinto Shrine|journal=Japanese Journal of Religious Studies|volume=23|year=1996|format=pdf|url=https://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/2589|pages=143–144}} ** {{Cite book|last=Nelson|first=John K.|title=Enduring Identities: The Guise of Shinto in Contemporary Japan|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|year=2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SPchlKNrj0UC&pg=PA47|page=47|isbn=978-0824822590}} * {{Cite book|last=Pfoundes|first=C.|title=Fu-so Mimo Bukuro: A Budget of Japanese Notes|publisher=Japan Mail|year=1875|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TiINAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA19|pages=19–20}} ;Japanese sources *{{citation|last=三橋|first=健|authorlink=:ja:三橋健 (神道学者)|ref=harv|title=決定版知れば知るほど面白い！ 神道の本|publisher=西東社|year=2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5gvJxI03v4UC&pg=PA164|pages=264–5|isbn=978-4791618163}} {{Refend}} {{Japanese folklore long}} {{DEFAULTSORT:ushinotokimairi}} [[Category:Japanese ghosts]] [[Category:Japanese folklore]] [[Category:Magic (paranormal)]] [[Category:Occult]] [[Category:Shamanism in Japan]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Companies of the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
Disambiguating links to [[Molestation]] (link changed to [[Sexual assault]]) using [[User:Certes/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:whatsitgoingtotake.png|right|thumb|The nine photographs produced for the campaign.
'''Top row (L-R)''': [[Honor Blackman]], [[Fern Britton]], [[Fiona Bruce]]
'''Middle row (L-R)''': [[Anne-Marie Duff]], [[Anna Friel]], [[Jemma Wellesley, Countess of Mornington|Jemma Kidd]]
'''Bottom row (L-R)''': [[Miquita Oliver]], [[Fay Ripley]], [[Kate Thornton]]]] '''''What's it going to take?''''' is a British [[newspaper advertisement|print]] and [[billboard|poster]] campaign launched in 2007 by [[Women's Aid]] to boost awareness of [[domestic violence]] against women in the United Kingdom. The campaign, handled by [[advertising agency]] [[Grey London]], comprised photographs of nine female celebrities [[make-up|made-up]] to appear as though they were the victims of domestic abuse. The campaign received substantial media attention, with commentary appearing in ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', ''[[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]'', and ''[[Marie Claire]]'', among others. The ''What's it going to take?'' campaign went on to win a number of honours within the advertising industry, including prizes at the 2008 Creative Circle Awards and the Aerial Awards. ==Background== [[Women's Aid Federation of England|Women's Aid]] was established in 1974 as an umbrella organisation for several [[feminism|feminist]] charities aiming to end [[domestic violence]] against women and children, including [[Sexual assault|molestation]], [[rape]], and [[sexual harassment]]. For the next thirty years, the organisation worked with a number of advertising agencies to promote its cause, including [[Ogilvy & Mather]],"Connections: OgilvyOne scoops Caples win for region", ''[[Media Asia Entertainment Group|Media Asia]]'', 8 March 2002. [[McCann Erickson]],Whitehead, Jennifer; "[http://www.brandrepublic.com/News/230535/Poster-ad-uses-Boxing-Day-line-fight-violence/ Poster ad uses Another Boxing Day line to fight violence]", ''Brand Republic'', 13 December 2004. Retrieved 23 May 2010. and [[Mediaedge:cia]]."[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/517312/Media-Strategy-Analysis---Tackling-domestic-violence-private/ Media: Strategy Analysis - Tackling domestic violence in private], ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 16 September 2005. Retrieved 23 May 2010. However, despite numerous publicity campaigns over the years, by 2005 the charity's own research suggested that less than 16% of the public were aware of the existence of Women's Aid. Through a personal relationship between a pair of employees at the two organisations, Women's Aid were taken on as a [[pro-bono]] client by agency [[Grey London]] in 2005."[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-195481669/pro-bono-work-agency.html Pro Bono Work: Agency Viewpoint - Grey London (Contract with Women's aid)]", ''[[Marketing Week]]'', 12 March 2009. Retrieved 23 May 2010."[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/search/519922/ Hotline: Grey London appointed to handle Women's Aid's account]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 30 September 2005. Retrieved 23 May 2010. The first product of this new collaboration was the 2006 ''[[Valentine's Day (advertisement)|Valentine's Day]]'' campaign. With a budget of £500, Grey London made strategic purchases of media space in newspapers and radio with a reach of about 2% of the UK population. Through an effective [[public relations]] campaign, this exposure was leveraged to the point where 52% of British adults saw the advertisements at least once. The campaign went on to win a number of awards in the advertising community, including an [[Effie Award|EFFIE Award]] for Socially Responsible Advertising and an IPA Effectiveness Award."[http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=208378 Grey EMEA Lands Hat-Trick at EACA Euro Effies]", ''[[PR Newswire]]'', 27 September 2007. Retrieved 23 May 2010.Sands, Marc; "[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/search/602959/IPA-Effectiveness-Awards-2006-Bronze-Awards/ IPA Effectiveness Awards 2006: Bronze Awards]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 3 November 2006. Retrieved 23 May 2010. Moreover, the campaign was financially successful. Women's Aid recorded an increase of 25% in traffic to their website and a substantial increase in the number of donations following ''Valentine's Day'''s run. ==Campaign== Looking to build upon the success of ''Valentine's Day'', Grey London began planning for a new campaign to run in early 2007. The brief for the campaign was to bring the issue into public view by making use of celebrities. In an interview with ''Creativity'' magazine, a planner for the agency said: "The amount of column inches and time spent talking about celebrities is phenomenal and if we could own even a small piece of this it would help to raise awareness of domestic violence and also Women's Aid. In this gossip driven world if we thought a celebrity was suffering from a form of domestic abuse EVERYONE would be talking about it.""AdCritic: Print and Design", ''Creativity'', February 2007. From this came the idea of a series of portraits of female celebrities made-up to appear as though they had been the victims of abuse. Grey London recruited [[fashion photographer]] [[Rankin (photographer)|Rankin]],"[http://www.campaignlive.com/thework/news/885316/Womens-Aid-whats-going-take-Grey-London/ Women's Aid 'what's it going to take?' by Grey London]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 31 January 2007. Retrieved 23 May 2010. known for his portraits of politicians and celebrities including [[Tony Blair]], [[Kylie Minogue]], and [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]],Walsh, John; "[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/rankin-an-image-maker-at-the-cutting-edge-of-fashion-589849.html Rankin: An image maker at the cutting edge of fashion]", ''[[The Independent]]'', 3 May 2003. Retrieved 23 May 2010. to conduct the shoot. The team approached a number of women to star in the campaign but, due to scheduling conflicts and the lack of a campaign budget, securing dates for the photo-shoot proved difficult. In all, nine female celebrities, across a wide range of ages and ethnicities, were chosen: [[Honor Blackman]], veteran actress and former [[Bond girl]]; [[Fern Britton]], presenter of daytime television show ''[[This Morning (TV series)|This Morning]]''; [[Fiona Bruce]], newsreader for BBC News; [[Anne-Marie Duff]], known for playing Fiona Gallagher on television drama ''[[Shameless (UK TV series)|Shameless]]''; [[Anna Friel]], known for playing Beth Jordache on the soap opera ''[[Brookside]]''; [[Jemma Wellesley, Countess of Mornington|Jemma Kidd]], former fashion model; [[Miquita Oliver]], television and radio personality; [[Fay Ripley]], known for playing Jenny Gifford in the comedy drama series ''[[Cold Feet]]''; and [[Kate Thornton]], journalist and television presenter."Celebrities act to end domestic violence" (press release), [[Women's Aid]] (2007). The head and shoulder prosthetics were created by Nigel Booth, whose previous work includes prosthetic and make-up design on feature films such as ''[[The English Patient (film)|The English Patient]]'' and ''[[Blade II]]''."Violence Against Violence", ''Creativity'', March 2007. The launch of the campaign on 1 February 2007 was celebrated with a launch party at [[11 Downing Street]] hosted by then-[[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Gordon Brown]] and his wife [[Sarah Jane Brown|Sarah]]. All appearances in magazines, newspapers, posters, on television and on radio were donated free of charge, as was the work of the featured celebrities, photographer, and the advertising agency."[http://www.womensaid.org.uk/page.asp?section=000100010010000600020001&itemTitle=Celebrity+Campaign+FAQ's Frequently Asked Questions]", [[Women's Aid]] website (2007). Retrieved 23 May 2010. In all, the campaign received an estimated £30m of media exposure,"Calling "Cut!" on Domestic Violence - How Women's Aid Used Celebrity to Change People's Minds" (case study), World Advertising Research Center (2009). including an eight-page feature in [[women's magazine]] ''[[Marie Claire]]'' with an editorial written by [[Marian Keyes]]. ===Reaction=== There was mixed reception to the campaign. Some were impressed with the impact of the images, such as Noel Bussey of [[Campaign (magazine)|''Campaign'' magazine]], who said: "Many agencies pull out their best work when it's for charity, but rarely is it this effective, so well shot or so close to the brief. The images of battered female celebrities are bound to pick up coverage outside of the original media, and will not fail in raising awareness about the sickening problem of domestic violence."Bussey, Noel; "[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/search/630775/Diary-Pick-week---Grey-Womens-Aid/ Diary: Pick of the week - Grey/Women's Aid]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 2 February 2007. Retrieved 23 May 2010. Others felt that the use of celebrities diminished the relevance of the message; Roisin Donnelly of [[Procter & Gamble]] commented: "In this print campaign, the celebrities, complete with injuries provided by the make-up artist, do get attention, but it seemed like it was a trick just to get attention, and was focused more on the celebrity and fake make-up rather than the central issue of domestic violence.""[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/633759/Work-Private-view/ The Work: Private view]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 16 February 2007. Retrieved 23 May 2010. Others were confused as to the point of the campaign; [[Kira Cochrane]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented: "The images were arresting, but odd. I can't imagine celebrity women posing as other sorts of victim: presenting themselves as trafficked women to highlight forced prostitution, or as rape victims to underline the low conviction rate. And what were the images supposed to tell us: that domestic violence is bad? Painful? Causes serious bruising?"Cochrane, Kira; "[https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/apr/03/domestic-violence-advertisement-keira-knightley Battered, Hollywood-style]", ''[[The Guardian]]'', 3 April 2009. Retrieved 23 May 2010. In all, the campaign proved a moderate success. Grey London reported that at the height of publicity for the campaign, more than 67% of the British public were aware of Women's Aid and its goals. The ''What's it going to take?'' campaign went on to win a number of awards from the advertising and charitable communities, including an Aerial Award for the radio component,"[http://www.aerialsfoundation.co.uk/ Archive: 2007 Winners]", Aerial Awards (2007). Retrieved 23 May 2010. a Silver Award at the 2008 Creative Circle Awards for the print component,"[http://www.creativecircle.co.uk/2008/silverhonours.htm Archive: 2008 Silver Honours]", Creative Circle Awards (2008). Retrieved 23 May 2010. and Women's Aid were honoured as the Campaigning Team of the Year at the Charity Times Gala Awards."[http://www.womensaid.org.uk/page.asp?section=0001000100190006§ionTitle=Our+awards Our Awards]", [[Women's Aid]] website (2007). Retrieved 23 May 2010. As of 2010, Grey London continues to produce work for Women's Aid; later in 2007, they collaborated again with Rankin to produce a second series of posters for the ''Valentine's Day'' campaign."[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/633757/Work-New-campaigns---UK/ The Work: New Campaigns]", ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign]]'', 16 February 2007. Retrieved 23 May 2010. In 2009 they continued to make use of celebrity to promote domestic abuse awareness, releasing a promotion starring [[Keira Knightley]], titled ''[[Cut (advertisement)|Cut]]''. The video, banned by the advertising standards agency [[Clearcast]] from appearing on British television,Shields, Rachel; "[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/too-violent-knightley-advert-banned-from-tv-1674393.html 'Too violent' Knightley advert banned from TV]", ''[[The Independent]]'', April 26, 2009. Retrieved 23 May 2010. was only shown online, backed by a print campaign pointing people to the website. ==External links== *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693308 "Anna"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693311 "Anne-Marie"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693314 "Fay"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.itv.com/Lifestyle/ThisMorning/Galleries/WomensAidcampaign/default.html "Fern"] at the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] website. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693312 "Fiona"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693315 "Honor"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693310 "Kate"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693309 "Jemma"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. *[http://www.adforum.com/creative-work/ad/player/6693313 "Miquita"] at ''The Advertising Forum''. ==References== {{reflist}} __NOTOC__ [[Category:2007 works]] [[Category:2007 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Advertisements]]
